headline: Lenovo Group Limited, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttext: Good morning, good evening. Welcome to Lenovo's Q3 result webcast. This is Gary Ng, VP in Investor Relations at Lenovo. Before we start, let me introduce our management team with us today. We have our Chairman and CEO, Mr. Yang Yuanqing; and our CFO, Mr. Wong Wai Ming. We will first start with our management presentation. After that, we'll take your questions. Now let me turn it over to Yuanqing.

headline: Lenovo Group Limited, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttext:
Hello, everyone. I hope your new year is off to a good start. This is a receding quarter for Lenovo. Many people, including myself, were curious to know whether our core business is remaining strong and even more, whether our private business is dragging our overall performance significantly behind. To be honest, this quarter's results are relatively complex. Even I spent more time than before to understand it, so I hope everyone here can be more patient when trying to understand. But after I fully understood it, I feel more confident than ever for Lenovo's future.
Our performance shows that not only we set a right strategy, choose the right acquisition targets but also executed it effectively, and it drove our overall business forward to hit our preset targets. Our core business, PCs, despite the unfavorable market conditions maintained its leading position and significantly improved profitability. Even more, our 2 newly acquired businesses have shown greater momentum in the first quarter of integration and that we have already started to see the synergies building to our plan start to deliver savings. This will become even more significant next year.
So this quarter, our revenue grow 31% year-on-year. And when you take out the M&A expenses such as intangible assets and interest expenses, our PTI was $348 million, up 8% year-on-year. Lenovo is now a far more balanced and diversified business. PC now accounts for only 65% of our overall business, mobile now at 24% and enterprise at 9%. The strong results from our new businesses make us even more confident that these 2 businesses will be our strong growth engines for PCs.
Although last quarter's market growth shifted from China emerging market to U.S. mature markets, we still kept our leadership position with a record 20% worldwide market share and significantly improved our profitability by 2 points year-on-year. Despite the challenges in Brazil, we achieved the profit growth in all other regions, particularly EMEA. Next, we will grasp the industry consolidation opportunity, and we are expanding more aggressively in the U.S. and Asia-Pacific consumer markets to gain even more market share. Back in fiscal year 2012, we committed to improve profitability by 1 point in 3 years with our core business. We are fully confident that we can achieve this target.
For mobile, we have challenges in China as the market shifted from carriers to open market, and the online sales continued to disrupt the market landscape and the business model. But our acquisition of Motorola proves our insights. Last quarter, Motorola, not only topped the sales volume from a year ago, sold over 10 million units in a quarter for the first time but also improved profitability at better-than-expected speed. Just last week, we announced the Moto's comeback to China. It will significantly enhance Motorola's overall performance. Even more important, Motorola will help us to become a true global player.  Overall, we are already the #3 smartphone company in the world. Last quarter, of our almost 25 million units sold, almost 60% of our volume come from outside China. Not only Motorola already covers over 50 countries, but the Lenovo brand has expanded into many European, Asia and American markets as well.
Just a few weeks ago, we launched our phone business in Turkey, which become the 67th country selling Lenovo smartphones. Definitely, China is still the most important smartphone market in the world, and we will keep fighting at a full force. We will significantly expand our online business whilst speed up the transformation of our traditional offline business. The first -- the online smartphone, Lemo receives very positive market response. We also established the Internet-model-based company, ShenQi, to fight the competitors head to head. At the same time, we will fully leverage Moto's China comeback to enhance our competitiveness in mid- and higher-end segments to further grow our business. And in tablets, we continue to grow share worldwide with EMEA leading the way, and our new Yoga tablet launch definitely created an excitement in the market.
In enterprise, although System x was affected by the acquisition and the market shift, our original ThinkServer business is very strong, grew 67%  year-on-year and partially made up the gap. Now we are #3 worldwide and the #1 in China. We have and will continue to quickly integrate our new global teams, build confidence in the market and with customers. And at the same time, we'll fully leverage the synergies and Lenovo's efficiency in supply, in R&D and in channels to enhance System x's competitiveness to achieve stability and the future growth target. We are confident that we will have a $5 billion business with a decent margin in 1 year.
Our ecosystem business also continued to grow. Lenovo store continues to go strong at 30 million daily downloads. Our most popular app, SHAREit, surpassed the 200 million users this quarter. In addition, our business transformation is strengthening our entire business from interactive product development to digital marketing, social media marketing and defense [ph] marketing. From expanding online sales and promoting China O2O transformation to build engagement service through community forums, every part of our business model is changing by leveraging the Internet.
Our product developers are engaged in customers each day to enhance our customer-centric innovation capability. Just last month, at the Consumer Electronics Show, we won a record 77 awards for our broad range of products and apps. Looking forward, our 3 business engines will all run at a full speed. We will deliver top line growth as well as profitability improvement to make our shareholders and customers proud.
Thank you everyone. Wish everyone a great Year of Sheep. Now let me turn this call to our CFO, Wai Ming.

headline: Lenovo Group Limited, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttext:
Thank you, Yuanqing. I will take you through Lenovo's financial and operational performance in quarter 3. Next chart, please. This is the first time we have included a full quarter of System x and 2 months of Motorola performance in our Q3 results. Our group revenue increased 31% year-to-year to $14.1 billion. The group PTI before noncash M&A-related accounting charges was $348 million, up 8% against last year. The noncash accounting charges related to the 2 M&A transactions was $74 million, which include intangible asset amortization, included interest expense of the 3-year promissory note issued as part of the Motorola transaction and others. Group PTI was $274 million, and group net income was $253 million, down 15% and 5% year-on-year, respectively. Group net income before noncash M&A-related accounting charges was $327 million, up 23% year-on-year during the quarter.
In addition to the noncash accounting charges, we have also incurred approximately $80 million in M&A-related cash expenses in Q3, comprises of $30 million loan interest expense, $40 million severance expense and a $10 million post-merger management expense that are aptly included in the USD 348 million in PTI before noncash M&A-related accounting charges. We have provided a bridge reconciling different financial figures in the chart after the financial summary page. We delivered solid performance with growth drivers from our new businesses, and we continue to be on track for our commitment to drive sustainable profitability improvements.
Next chart please. This slide gives you a more detailed view of our financial performance for the quarter. As mentioned in the previous slide, our group revenue gross profit and adjusted PTI improved year-on-year driven by solid growth of our core PC business and the 2 acquired businesses. Gross profit increased 54% year-on-year with margin improving to 14.9%. Operating expenses increased by 72% to around $1.8 billion. The increase in sales and E/R ratio in Q3 is mainly driven by the 2 new M&As. We recorded net other nonoperating expenses of $51 million, which mainly included the interest expense of $16 million accrued for the USD 1.5 billion 5-year note we issue in early May, factoring cost of $16 million as well as $7 million of the 2-month included interest expense for the promissory note related to the Motorola transaction. PTI was reported $274 million.
The effective tax rate for Q3 was 6.3%. This is lower than last year largely due to the tax benefit associated with the newly acquired businesses. Profit for the period was $257 million, and profit attributable to equity holders was $253 million. The difference between the 2 profit lines was due to our joint venture partners sharing gain in relation to the compound joint venture recorded in Q3. Basic EPS was USD 0.0232 compared to USD 0.0256 last year. 
Next chart, please. In this chart, we have provided a bridge to reconcile different financial figures that I mentioned earlier to give you an overview and how these figures are calculated.
Next chart, please. Our balance sheet remains strong and include System x and Motorola. The key difference compared to the quarter that ended in September is largely due to the inclusion of the 2 transaction closed in quarter 3 and our normal business activities. The noncurrent assets were about $11.4 billion, and current assets were about $17.8 billion as of 31st December 2014, where net current liabilities of around $1.3 billion at the end of December and noncurrent liabilities was around $5.9 billion.
Let's go through the cash and working capital on the next chart. Our cash position remained very healthy. As of the end of December, we have net cash of around $1.3 billion. The quarter-on-quarter decrease of our bank deposits and cash was mainly due to the payment of cash consideration of about $2.3 billion for the acquisition of System x and Motorola in quarter 3. We also drew down a loan amounting to $600 million from our existing loan facilities in December 2014, which resulted in our increase of total bank borrowing levels. If we add back cash consideration pay for the 2 M&A transactions, our net cash position in Q3 is even better year-on-year and quarter-on-quarter.
We continue to do well in managing our working capital. The cash conversion cycle quarter 3 was negative 2 days, flat year-on-year and against negative 5 days last quarter. The cash conversion cycle of our core business continue to see gradual improvements. The newly acquired businesses had a slightly positive working capital in the first quarter of integration, and we expect this to improve over time. We have recorded net cash generated from operation of $738 million in quarter 3 against $1 billion the same quarter last year. The year-on-year quarter-on-quarter changes are mainly due to the change in net working capital. Our cash flow from operations remain healthy for supporting our drive for future growth.
Next chart, please. This slide shows the revenue mix of our business by business group and geography. We now have a much more diversified and balanced business portfolio to drive sustainable growth. From a business group perspective, our PC business now account for about 65% of our total revenue compared to 81% the same quarter last year, the high contribution from faster growing new businesses, including mobile and enterprise, which accounted for about 24% and 9% of our total revenue, respectively. From a geographic perspective, businesses outside China accounted for about 71% of our total revenue compared to about 63% last year.
Next chart, please. As Yuanqing mentioned earlier, our overall business is much more diversified. We want to give you more color on the business group performance. For our PC business group, despite challenges in Brazil, we achieved profit growth with share gain in all geographies, particularly in EMEA. Our PC revenue increased 5% year-on-year to $9.2 billion with a record high pretax income of $494 million and pretax margin of 5.4%, which is up 2 points year-on-year, while we kept our leadership position with a record 20% worldwide PC market share. We will grasp the industry consolidation opportunity and expand more aggressively in the U.S. and Asia-Pacific consumer markets to gain even more market share.
Mobile Business Group includes Lenovo mobile business that consists of phone, tablets and TV businesses and 2 months of Motorola's business. The revenue of this business group increased 109% year-on-year to $3.4 billion driven by the strong growth of Motorola business. Our mobile PTI recorded a loss of $89 million, and pretax margin was negative 2.6%. Motorola performance continued to gain momentum and assuming even more than double year-on-year in Q3, while market growth is 28% year-on-year. In addition, Moto operation result was positively impacted by having over 80% of its volume slowed in the last 2 months of the quarter. While monthly expense do not generally have significant variation within the quarter, this positive impact on financial result in Q3 will not repeat in Q4.
Our smartphone business in China continue to be challenging as various subsidies were cut, driving shipments through carrier channel down nearly 30%, while Internet sales took off. Both factors disrupted the market, and this affected negatively our phone business in China. With the addition of Motorola to the smartphone portfolio, it enhances our overall markets coverage and create a much more balanced mobile business on a global basis. Moto back to China will also address the high-end segment opportunities and hence, improve the overall profitability.
As we enter into the full quarter, which is 4Q financial year '15, which is typically a low season for Lenovo and Motorola, both businesses will have a low seasonality sales, will usually be down 20% to 30% quarter-to-quarter. And as a result, margin typically will be low. We remain confident we will turn around the Motorola business within 4 to 6 quarters from close.
As in tablet, our new Yoga tablet launch definitely created excitement in the market. In Q3, we continue to outgrow the market with EMEA leading the way. Our worldwide tablet shipments were up 9% year-on-year being the worldwide #3 and the fastest-growing vendor among the top 5, while our market share continued to expand.
Revenue of the Enterprise Business Group showed an increase of 6.9x year-on-year to $1.2 billion, which include a full quarter of System x business. Our ThinkServer business was very strong. The System x business continued to record decline during the first quarter of integration. PTI of the combined server and storage business recorded a loss of $42 million, and pretax margin is negative 3.4%. We fully leveraged the synergies and Lenovo efficiency in supply chain, R&D and channel to enhance System x competitiveness to achieve stability and future growth targets. At the same time, we will improve its efficiency and ensure its cost structure is competitive.
In Q3, we announced a voluntary buyout program to rightsize the workforce. Our commitment in EBG to drive $5 billion sales revenue with a margin better than our PC business remains the same.
Next chart, please. Our geographic exposure is also very balanced to support our future growth. Our business now have a more diversified product portfolio with high mix of non-PC business in each of the geos. As such, we have modified the presentation in the chart slightly from this quarter onwards to review our performance in each geography from an overall perspective.
Total revenue from China geography was slightly up year-on-year. Profit went up 7% year-on-year. Our overall margin was up 0.3% -- point year-on-year. Our PC business continued to perform well despite market decline and achieved a record market share of 38.2% while holding up its margin well. Even though competition in China smartphone market is very keen and the market is no longer seeing hyper growth as we mentioned earlier, it is still the most important smartphone market in the world. We are fighting back in China with plans Yuanqing mentioned earlier. For Enterprise business, combining our existing business and System x, Lenovo has become the largest server maker in China. Integration of System x so far has been smooth. We will continue the integration work to ensure the planned synergies can be delivered.
In Q3, AP geo revenue was up 7% year-on-year to achieve $1.7 billion in Asia Pacific. Profit went up 271% year-on-year. Our overall operating margin improved substantially by 3.9 points year-on-year to 5.4%. We strategically protected Japan PC leadership despite a declining Japan PC market while improving margin to achieve record high operating profit for the quarter. At the same time, we attacked India PC market with shipment growth as well as overall operating margin improvement. Therefore, our PC business continued to gain share and achieved record high market share at 16.1%. During the quarter, the 2 newly acquired business also helped the overall top line growth of the AP region. Motorola performed very well in the region, especially in India, which helped the strong growth of the combined smartphone shipment of Asia-Pacific region. For enterprise, we continue to leverage Lenovo channel expertise and supply chain efficiency to accelerate the enterprise business in the region.
EMEA revenue was up 40% year-to-year to above $4 billion. Profit was up 135% year-on-year. Our overall margin improved by 1.2 points year-on-year to 3%. Our PC and mobile business continued to record strong momentum before Motorola and System x. Our PC business continued to gain share and achieved record high market share at 19.6% driven mainly by the consumer business in Western Europe and Middle East and Africa. In smartphone, we recorded strong growth in EMEA driven by the momentum both from Motorola and Lenovo, thanks to the strong shipment performance from Lenovo brand in the Eastern Europe and Middle East and Africa regions. On Enterprise business, we will be more aggressive in attacking growth in the region's enterprise segment.
Americas revenue was up 88% year-on-year to about $4.3 billion largely due to the adding of System x and Motorola business. We recorded a loss of $22 million in the region largely due to the challenges in Brazil and ramping up of newly acquired businesses. For PC, we continue to deliver solid growth in PC business in North America region driven by the balanced growth in both consumer and commercial businesses. PC unit shipment in North America increased 6% year-on-year with margin improvement year-on-year. With the contribution of strong shipment performance from Motorola, our smartphone shipment grew substantially in AG this quarter. For Enterprise, we are preparing our foundation to attack and capture more enterprise customers in future. However, our performance in Brazil is still impacted by the weak market environment affected by the local macroeconomic issues that resulted in weak demand and high inventory in the industry. Currency fluctuation also negatively impacted both Lenovo and Motorola performance despite the strong revenue momentum. We have been refining our business strategy in PC, and actions are in place to stabilize the Brazil business. Proactive actions taken to improve our performance include simplifying product portfolio, improving operational controls and improving supply chain efficiency, and a new local leadership is in place to execute our strategy.
Looking ahead, we are confident that the group business will continue to outperform the market across our key products to drive profitability growth and margin execution. We are building a solid foundation for transforming us into a truly global and diversified company with 3 group of businesses. We will continue to leverage Motorola to accelerate our phone expansion and enhance our MBG performance and to take actions to stabilize the EBG business and optimize its expense structure to improve its operating efficiency. We now have a much broader product portfolio, and we'll continue to leverage our extensive channel network already established in the past several years to drive future growth. We're devoted to driving growth and outperform from scaling and operating efficiency enhancement and in turn, enhancing our profitability over time.
Thank you. Now we can take your questions.

headline: Lenovo Group Limited, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] The first question comes from the line of Gokul Hariharan of JPMorgan.

headline: Lenovo Group Limited, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttext: I have a couple of questions. First of all, on the Motorola side, looks like the profitability is getting a bit better, and the volume momentum is also quite strong. Could you also outline what are the strategies for Motorola especially on the cost side of things since you mentioned that you have some actions over the next 12 months to get the business back to breakeven? Could you outline what exactly those actions are likely to be? And I have a follow-up as well.

headline: Lenovo Group Limited, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttext: Okay. Thank you. So definitely. So Motorola is -- so performance last quarter proved also that this is the right acquisition plan -- so target. Not only -- so not only last quarter, they grew their volume by more than 100%. And the first time reached the 10 million volume worldwide. Actually, it's 10.6 million. But also, they significantly improved their profitability. So that gave us more confidence, so we can turn around this business in another 3 to 5 quarters that we promised. So we -- now we understand this business better. So actually, Motorola has much better gross margin than the normal smartphone or even the Lenovo PC. But unfortunately, today, their E/R ratio is higher -- much higher than Lenovo smartphone and Lenovo PC. So that's why it can give us more confidence that we can, I think give us a better profit in the future. So we -- definitely, we are fully leveraging Lenovo more efficient operational platform and so -- particularly in the supply chain side. So we are very confident we can help them to reduce the material costs. So actually, by now we have identified probably $0.5 billion, so majority cost of synergy, so over next 12 years -- 12 months, I'm sorry, over next 12 months. So that's one thing.  Definitely, we can further help them to reduce the E/R, so through the better manufacturing cost and other also operational cost. So that will be our strategy. We will -- and by the way, we will maintain Motorola as an independent brand and organization so that they can keep this strong momentum. So actually, Motorola has a strong presence in North America and Latin America. So a reason that -- so we have seen the first established success in India. So over the past 10 months, actually, we sold 3 million units in India through our main [ph] channel. So we have become a very decent player in that market. So -- and also, definitely, another important action is we bring Motorola back to China. So we launched that last week. So actually, we will start shipment a couple of days later. So that will help Lenovo to strengthen our product portfolio in the high end -- in the middle to the high end in China. So we have got a lot of positive feedback on Motorola product in China. So actually, in -- within just 1 week, so now we have already received 1 million [indiscernible] received the order from the consumers, but definitely not 100% will be converted to the real sales. But it's very strong momentum. So definitely, we can count on Motorola to help strengthen our smartphone position in China as well.

headline: Lenovo Group Limited, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttext: Just to clarify, Yuanqing, $500 million of cost synergies over the next 12 months, right? That's what you're expecting for Motorola?

headline: Lenovo Group Limited, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttext: Yes. $400 million to $500 million, yes, so around that range.

headline: Lenovo Group Limited, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttext: And just one more question on the PC margin side. The PC margin was much higher than what we have seen in the recent quarters, probably 1 to 2 percentage points higher than what we have seen. Could you explain a little bit more, especially in Asia-Pacific, what drove this big change given that you also had some currency-related issues? Also, how much of it is at a scalable kind of margin level? Are we going to be at that 5% kind of pretax margin for PC going forward?

headline: Lenovo Group Limited, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttext: Yes. So our PC performance last quarter was pretty strong, so although the market is not in favor to us. So actually, China and the emerging market actually what we are thinking, so U.S. and the mature market are growing. So that's actually favored to our competitors, which are based in U.S. But we performed very well, so very [indiscernible]. Actually, I mean, we keep our #1 position, but also we improved our PTI ratio by 2 points. So now we -- for the first time, we delivered more than 5% PTI, actually, 5.4% PTI. So that's -- that is 2 points year-on-year improvement. So that's amazing improvement. So why we can deliver that? Because -- I think mainly because our strategy. So if you still can remember, so a couple of years ago, we set a strategy to attack the consumer market particularly in EMEA. So actually, when we executed that strategy, after the first stage, we lost money. We lost money. But when we reached certain -- a percent of the market shift, so the profitability will be improved significantly, actually, so like in EMEA. So things basically are just the same this fiscal year. We started to make money from the consumer space but over -- past 2 to 3 years, we lost money. So that's a significant headwind to improve the overall profitability in the PC space. So with this strategy, I believe, so more and more regions will gain 10%, 15% or even 20% market share. But probably, today, if you cannot reach 15% to 20% market share, it's hard to make money, particularly in the consumer space. But we believe more and more region and countries that we have reached that target. So that will help us to improve the profitability, so we are still confident that so we can -- but definitely, last quarter was a fantastic quarter, but we are confident that we can maintain like the 5% PTI in the PC space.

headline: Lenovo Group Limited, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttext: Yes, Gokul, this is Wai Ming. I just gave you -- think Yuanqing gave you a perspective of the, I think, the overall business. So I'll give you a perspective from a numbers point of view. I think the excellent execution of my colleagues actually enabled -- a lot of the margins is actually really derived from the scaling benefit, meaning that we continue to grow top line, but we actually be able to manage expenses in a very, very good way. And therefore, I think a large part of the improvement, I think, is really coming out from the scaling benefit. And really, from a geography perspective, I think literally, I think, all regions, I think except Brazil, which we already called out, which we mentioned about the issues, more -- all regions, in fact, actually increase market share as well as profitability. It's actually a worldwide scale. And again, really want you -- sort of, I think, go back to Yuanqing's point that I think the execution, the scaling benefit, I think building up market share is absolute critical and also, I think also from my [ph] view that I think the PC business is actually a very attractive business, and the strong performance actually give us, I think, the result that we reported today.

headline: Lenovo Group Limited, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttext: Justed want to clarify, is currency headwinds in the last quarter for you guys? Or is the margin performance even despite 3 FX headwinds because these are big margin improvement in both EMEA as well as Asia Pacific where currencies have been quite volatile?

headline: Lenovo Group Limited, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttext: Gokul, let's restrict it to the 2 questions at a time. We'll talk to you later.

headline: Lenovo Group Limited, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttext: And the next question comes from the line of Kirk Yang of Barclays.

headline: Lenovo Group Limited, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttext: This is Kirk Young from Barclays. My question is actually on your enterprise business. I think you mentioned earlier that you still maintain your guidance to reach about USD 5 billion with OP margins better than PC, which is above 5%. But for the December quarter, I see that your enterprise business pretax margin was actually minus 3.4%. So maybe can you please give us some colors for the reasons for the minus margin? And what is your plan to reverse that into positive in the near future?

headline: Lenovo Group Limited, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttext: Yes. So thank you, Kirk, for the question. So actually, so now the System x business that we bought from IBM, so the key issue is not on the bottom line. It's on the top line. So actually, so last quarter, their revenue declined by more than 20%, more than 20%. With that decline under the sudden [ph] expense, so definitely, you cannot expect the good PTI. So the reason -- the first challenge so are in twofold. The first is -- the first thing is the cost competitiveness. So IBM always run the business at a very premium level part, not just product but also the cost structure. So that makes their business not competitive in the market. And the second one is actually those -- there's a new business model, so -- which is the ODM -- OEMs that direct the sale to the -- those Internet companies, particularly for the data center part. So we call it the IPDC market. So actually, this model is disrupting not just IBM but also -- actually, and Dell as well. So actually, you can see Dell server business actually declining as well. So that's the reason. So -- but meanwhile, so I wish you could see another result. Actually, Lenovo ThinkServer business are growing much faster than that. So actually, last quarter, we grew by 67% year-on-year, so that partially compensated the revenue decline of the System x. But our server business space is very limited, so -- and we only sell in very limited countries. But now with the joining of the System x not only we can have the full product portfolio. In the past, Lenovo's product portfolio only covered the low-end servers. But IBM definitely can cover mid- to high end. So now we have the full range of the product portfolio. And also, System x also covered more regions and countries, so that gave us more coverage. They have a good brand. They have good technology. They have good customers. But now the only problem is they are not competitive. They're not competitive. But efficiency has always been Lenovo's stronghold, so we definitely believe we can help this business to be more competitive with more efficient procurement, manufacturing, logistics or even in R&D area. So we have a lot of room to improve. So we have already made the plan. We will take the action quickly to improve the competitiveness to stabilize the business. Over time, we even should grow the business, so it's definitely. So that's still our commitment, to build a $5 billion business with a better PC margin. So if we can hit the top line, so I don't think the bottom line is a problem -- is the issue.

headline: Lenovo Group Limited, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttext: And the next question comes from the line of Arthur Hsieh of UBS.

headline: Lenovo Group Limited, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttext: I have 2 questions. First is just wondering in management's mind what would you consider as a successful relaunch of the Motorola brand in China. The reason why I'm asking is because China is the most competitive smartphone market in the world, and looking at MIDH, even though it's already #1, it was not really profitable. I mean, it was maybe slightly profitable. But with this new investment of Motorola brand marketing in China, potentially this could be further burden in terms of the cost. So I mean, how important is the relaunch of the China business for Motorola? Or actually, is more of a marketing and real profit could more come from the overseas expansion? That's the first question.

headline: Lenovo Group Limited, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttext: Okay. Thank you. So I think Motorola back to China is important for both Motorola business and our China smartphone business. We definitely would not sacrifice the profit part to expand the market. So we still -- actually, we also have the good margin in China, so -- but Motorola will help our China  smartphone business because, in the past, with the Lenovo brand smartphone, we can only cover low-end products, so actually, we sell more product through the carriers. We are very hard to enter into the market above RMB 2,000 -- about RMB 2,000. But with Motorola brand, now it definitely could be chance for us to address the mid- to high-end market. So actually, Moto X will sell at about RMB 3,000. So Moto G will sell at around RMB 1,200 to RMB 1,500. So that's a good complement -- that's a very good complement. So that's why -- so that will help our China smartphone business. We will -- by the way, so we will mainly sell Motorola through the online, so that we'll help us through online retailers. So that will help us to strengthen our open market coverage and the online coverage. So that's for China, definitely for Motorola overall business because we don't sacrifice the GP margin. So with the large volume -- with the addition of the China volume, so definitely, that will kind of further help Motorola to improve their profitability. So that's why I said that for both China smartphone business and the overall Motorola business, this strategy is critical.

headline: Lenovo Group Limited, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttext: And second question is about the EMEA business. I think in terms of the currency, it was very unfavorable in the last quarter, but you still managed to deliver both sales and earnings growth there even with the slight margin downside. The question is how much more potential room in terms of a share gain there. And how is the currency outlook potential impact to this business? Is there going to be further impacted margin? Or potentially, you could stabilize around like 3%, that kind of OP margin in that region.

headline: Lenovo Group Limited, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, May 21, 2015
componenttext:
Good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to the investor presentations of Lenovo. First, let me introduce the management with us today. They are Mr. Yang Yuanqing, Chairman and CEO; Mr. Gianfranco Lanci, Corporate President and COO; and Mr. Wong Wai Ming, our CFO.
Today, we are very excited to share with you a new look and feel, the new brand of Lenovo, which will be officially introduced at Lenovo Tech World on next Thursday in Beijing. The new brand carries the never-stand-still attitude, as you see, and the energy of Lenovo and is designed to be digital-first, social-first and dynamic. We will definitely share with you more about the new brand going forward.
Without further ado, let me start our -- let us start our earnings presentation. We will first have Yuanqing to present and followed by Wai Ming.
Now may I invite Yuanqing to come on stage for his presentation? Yuanqing, please.

headline: Lenovo Group Limited, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, May 21, 2015
componenttext:
Thank you. Hello, everyone. [indiscernible] because now it becomes a once-a-year event to see you in person. But I'm very excited to share our performance in a historical year and discuss about our future strategy.
Last quarter, we again delivered strong results. Our revenue grew 21% year-on-year or, actually, 28%, if we're excluding exchange rate impact, reaching $11.3 billion. Earnings before M&A accounting charges increased 23% year-on-year to USD 194 million. We had a strong performance in all our businesses, led by our PC Group, which has now held the #1 position for 8 straight quarters. We gained share in every geo an improved margin by 1 point year-on-year and reached 5.5%.
In smartphones, we gained more than 1 point of share, actually, 1.2 points year-on-year, led by Motorola, which grew more than 23% year-on-year, although it's not as fast as previous quarters, but this is still a very decent growth; and also by rapid growth outside of China, where our volume was more than 5x the previous year. Volume outside China this quarter was 56% of our total smartphone volume. In tablets, we gained more than 1 point of share, so actually, 1.3 points, and we remained the #3 worldwide in both smartphone and tablets. 
In Enterprise, our legacy ThinkServer revenue grew more than 40%. System x, which was bought from IBM, revenue decline narrowed to 5%, but the operational margin improved by 4.2 points, reaching 2.7%. So last year, it was a loss business. But this year, our -- so we successfully turned it around. And our Ecosystem business continued to grow and now has 70 million monthly active users. Our strong quarter finished the record fiscal year.
For the fiscal year, our revenue reached a record of more than USD 46 billion, up 20% year-on-year. Excluding M&A accounting charges, we had a record net income of almost $1 billion, up 22% year-on-year. In the fiscal year, we shipped almost 60 million PCs to reach an all-time high share -- market share of 19.7% and grew at an 11-point premium to the market.
In Mobile, with Moto joining, we achieved a record volume of 76 million. And in tablets, we gained 1 point of share year-on-year, outgrowing the market more than 24 points. In Enterprise, ThinkServer revenue grew almost 50%. System x showed the first steps of success of our thorough and quick integration with revenues stabilizing gradually and the profit improved. Ecosystem business has generated 400 million users worldwide, up 300% year-on-year, and it generated USD 167 million revenue.
3 years ago, we made a commitment to improve our operational margin of legacy business, that's excluding Motorola and System x, by at least 1 point. We have overachieved that commitment, actually increasing this number from 2% in fiscal year '11/'12 to 3.2% in year '14/'15. These strong results show the formula for success that I always talk about: clear strategy, innovative products, operational excellence and a diverse global team and culture. It's clearly working, yet we are not satisfied and have a clear strategy for growth in the year ahead.
Motorola and System x integration are both on track. For both of these businesses, we are definitely confident in our strategic direction, while we also recognize we are still building a foundation for the future. It will take time for these to become additional core business for Lenovo. But we remain confident to build our $5 billion Enterprise Business with a stronger profit 1 year after closing, and we remain firm on turning Motorola around in 4 to 6 quarters after closing.
Our balanced growth and our acquisitions make Lenovo a significantly more diverse businesses. In products, PC has gone from more than 80% of revenue in the first half of the fiscal year to 64% in the second. Even with record PC performance, Mobile and Enterprise Business each accounts for 25% and 9%. And in geographies, China now only accounts for 32% of our total revenue; EMEA, E-M-E-A, 28%; Americas, 26%; and Asia Pacific, 14%.
In the year ahead, we will continue to execute our "protect and attack" strategy with the updated forecasts. In PCs, we will fully leverage the industry consolidation, leverage innovation and leverage our scale and efficiency to grow our share and protect our profit pool. In Enterprise, we will leverage synergies between System x and ThinkServer and between PC and Enterprise to fund the growth. We will further reduce costs, protect our leadership position in China and expanding into global data center and cloud service market.
In smartphones, we will grow with our dual-brand strategy. Motorola brand will enhance this position in North America, Latin America and Europe by significantly improving efficiency, and the Lenovo brand will focus on China and growing other emerging markets. In tablets, we will drive sales globally by leading in innovation. Ecosystem will continue to expand the Lenovo's user base and provide greater applications and user experience.
To ensure better forecast, we reorganized the company, combining PC and the Enterprise Businesses to leverage the synergy in R&D, supply chain and procurement, and opportunities in channels and customer base. Our President and COO, Gianfranco, focuses on overseeing that part of the business. Mobile, ECS and IoT are more interrelated and have untapped growth potential, so I am focusing more on these areas.
In this Internet-plus [ph] era, Lenovo will embrace a new vision to transform from a product-centric to a customer-centric company. To do that, first, we are moving from making mostly hardware to a fusion of hardware, software and cloud services. With our devices and our infrastructure and cloud capabilities, users can better connect with their devices, personal data and services, and the devices can better connect with networks and other devices in a most reliable, smooth and secure way.
Second, we are moving from onetime purchase to multiple touch points with customers, even in just the individual consumer customers. So these touch points will be before, during and, more importantly, after purchase. These are bold aspirations, but we are determined and have aligned the company to work towards this direction.
Before I close, I want to mention that Lenovo will showcase its innovative products, prototypes and overall picture of innovation direction at the Lenovo Tech World in Beijing on May 28. We also will reveal our new brand, our younger look and feel, more energetic and vibrant. Many Lenovo fans will be there to share our excitement.
Last year was a record year for Lenovo, but we will never stand still. Now we are prepared to unlock substantial growth across our company, which is now more diverse and balanced than ever before.
Thank you, everyone. Now let me turn this to our CFO, Wai Ming.

headline: Lenovo Group Limited, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, May 21, 2015
componenttext:
Good afternoon, everybody. Thank you, Yuanqing. I will now take you through Lenovo financial and operational performances in Q4 and our fiscal year 2015. Next chart, please. Fiscal year 2015 is another record year for Lenovo. Group revenue increased 20% year-on-year to a record high of $46.3 billion, which obviously included the 2 quarters of System x and 5 months of Motorola financial performance. If we exclude the currency impact, the group revenue will have increased 23% year-on-year.
Group PTI before noncash M&A-related accounting charges was $1.139 billion, up 12% against last year. The noncash accounting charges related to the 2 M&A transactions were $168 million, which include the intangible asset amortization, the imputed interest expense on the 3-year promissory note issued as part of the Motorola transaction. Group PTI was $971 million, down 4%; and group net income was $829 million, up 1% year-on-year. Group net income before the noncash M&A-related accounting charges was $997 million, up 22% year-on-year for the fiscal year, the record high level for net income in our corporate history.
In addition to the noncash accounting charges, we have also incurred approximately $197 million in M&A-related cash expenses for the year, comprised of expense, mostly the loan interest expenses, severance payment as well as the postmerger management expenses that is included in our PTI before the noncash M&A-related accounting charges. We have provided a bridge reconciling these different financial figures in the chart after the financial summary page. We delivered a very solid performance with growth drivers from the new businesses, and we continue to be on track for our commitment to drive sustainable profitability improvement.
Next chart, please. This slide gives you a more detailed view of our financial performance for the fiscal year and quarter 4. The results reflected this -- the results reflected a solid growth of our legacy PC business and the 2 acquired businesses. Gross profit increased 32% year-on-year with margin improved to 14.4%, driven by the higher gross margin, the Motorola and System x businesses.
Operating expense increased by 39% to around $5.6 billion. There's increase in E/R ratio for the fiscal year, and that is primarily driven by the 2 acquired businesses. We recorded net other operating expenses of $137 million, mainly included the interest expenses accrued for the USD 1.5 billion 5-year notes issued in early May last year, the interest -- the imputed interest expenses on the promissory notes, as well as some factoring cost and foreign currencies expenses.
The effective tax rate for the fiscal year was 13.8%. It's lower than last year, again, due to the tax benefit associated with the 2 businesses we acquired. Profit for the period was $837 million, and profit attributable to equity holders was $829 million. The difference between the 2 profit lines were due to our joint venture partner sharing of the gain in relation to our Compal joint venture recorded in the fiscal year.
In Q4, we have included a full quarter of Motorola and System x financial performances. Revenue is up 21% year-to-year to around $11.3 billion. Excluding the foreign currency impact, the group revenue will have been increased by 28%. Gross profit was up 43% year-on-year to $1.8 billion. Margin increased by 2.4 points year-on-year to 15.7%, again, with the help of the 2 M&A transactions -- 2 M&A businesses.
Operating profit decreased by 45% year-to-year to $127 million due to the high E/R of the 2 businesses that we acquired. Other nonoperating expenses was $23 million, mainly attributable to the increase in the bond interest, again, the imputed interest from the promissory note and the factoring cost.
If we exclude the noncash M&A-related accounting charges of $94 million for the quarter, the pretax income was $198 million, down 7% year-to-year; and profit attributable to equity holders was $194 million, up 23% year-on-year. The reported pretax income was $104 million, and the reported profit attributable to equity holders was $100 million. Basic EPS for the year, USD 0.0777 compared to USD 0.0788 last year. The board declared in the meeting this morning to declare a final dividend of HKD 0.205 per share.
Next chart, please. Now this chart actually will provide a bridge to reconcile all the different financial figures that I mentioned earlier to give you a much better view on how our performance include -- after excluding those M&A-related cash or noncash expenses.  
Next chart, please. Looking at the balance sheet. The main driver for the change in our balance sheet is the inclusion of the Motorola and the System x businesses. Noncurrent assets were about $11.7 billion, and current assets were about $15.4 billion as of 31st of March 2015. We have net current liabilities around $1.7 billion. The change was due to, again, the inclusion of the 2 M&A businesses. The noncurrent liabilities was around $5.8 billion.  
Next chart, please. Looking at the cash and working capital. Operating cash flow for the year is $238 million, was net of an investment in working capital for our Motorola and System x businesses. Both acquired businesses currently are not run on a negative cash conversion cycle basis. We are taking actions to bring both businesses to be in line with our existing business model, which is -- are run on a negative cash conversion cycle. We will continue to drive improvement of our balance sheet by rearranging part of our short-term borrowings into long-term facilities. 
At the end of March, we had net borrowings of around $28 million, but that exclude the $1.5 billion promissory note that we issued to Google. The change was due to working capital and also capital expenditure. Cash conversion cycle for the fiscal year was negative 2 days, flat year-on-year. The cash conversion cycle for quarter 4 was positive 3 days against the negative 4 days same quarter last year and negative 2 days last quarters. Again, the deviation is primarily driven from the 2 businesses we acquired.
Next chart, please. Our overall business is much more diversified. We continue to drive profit improvement from our core PC business and drive top line growth through our Mobile and Enterprise Group, which are our new growth engines. For the PC business, despite the challenges in Brazil, we achieved profit growth with share gain in all geographies, particularly in EMEA. For the fiscal year, our PC revenue increased 5% year-on-year to $33.3 billion with a record high pretax income of $1.8 billion and pretax margin of 5.3%, up 1.6 points year-to-year. The group continue to leverage the industry consolidation and enhance our leadership position, with better scale helping the PC profit margin.
On Mobile Business Group. That includes our legacy phone, Lenovo phone, tablet and our TV business and 5 months of Motorola businesses. The revenue of this business group increased 71% year-on-year to $9.1 billion, driven by the inclusion of the Motorola business. PTI recorded a loss of $370 million, and the pretax margin was negative 4%. Our legacy smartphone business continued to see tremendous growth in markets outside of China, growing by 126% year-to-year for the fiscal year. Our smartphone business in China, however, continue to be challenging as the carrier subsidies were cut, driving shipments through carrier channel to trend down, while the Internet sales increased with income addition from other plays. Both factors disrupted the market and negatively affected our phone business in China.
Integration of Motorola was on track to turnaround in 4 to 6 quarters since the deal closed. Motorola enhanced its position in its core markets, such as in Latin America, U.S. and India. In quarter 3, Motorola operating result was positively impacted by the higher volume sold in the last 2 months when we consolidated the accounts. In quarter 4, however, Motorola operation result were back to its normal full quarter run rate and continue to see -- and we continue to see profitability improvements. And for tablets, our worldwide tablet shipment was up 26% year-on-year with strong growth in markets outside of China. Tablet shipments outside China now represent approximately 87% of our global volume.
Enterprise Business. Revenue showed an increase of 4.2x year-on-year to $2.6 billion, which include 2 quarters of System x businesses. Our ThinkServer business continued to show strong growth, while System x business started to show signs of stabilization during the first 2 quarters of integration. PTI for the combined server and storage business recorded a loss of $121 million and pretax margin of a negative 4.6%. We will fully leverage the synergies and Lenovo's strength in the supply chain, R&D and channel to enhance the System x competitiveness to achieve stability and future growth targets. At the same time, we will improve its efficiency and ensure that its cost structure is competitive. Our '15/'16 commitment in the Enterprise Business Group is to drive $5 billion sales revenue, where the good margin remains exactly the same.
Next chart, please. Performance by geography. Our geographic exposure is also very balanced to support our future growth. Looking at China. Total revenue from China was down marginally year-on-year. However, profit was up 1% year-on-year. Our overall margin in China was flat year-on-year to 5.4%, as China's smartphone industry challenges negatively affected our Mobile Business in the country. And we had also invested this year to bring the Moto back to China to drive sustainable growth over time. Our PC business continued to perform well despite the market decline, with the market share improved year-on-year by 1.5 points to 36.6%, while holding up its margin well. For smartphone, we are charging back in China by continuing to expand this business through more routes to market, including online and also new channel from ShenQi and also a broader portfolio of Lenovo and Motorola products.
For Asia Pacific. The revenue was up 6% year-on-year to about $6.6 billion in Asia Pacific. Profits was up 1.8x year-on-year. Our overall operating margin improved substantially by 2.8 points year-on-year to 4.6%. PC business continued to gain share and achieve record high market share. The better operational efficiency from scaling benefits helped to -- the profitability improvement of the geography. Motorola performed very well in the region, especially in India, which helped strong growth of the combined smartphone shipment of Asia Pacific region to double in the fiscal year.
For EMEA. EMEA, the revenue was up 34% year-on-year to about $12.8 billion; profit, up 1.2x year-on-year. Our overall margin improved by 1.2 points year-on-year to 3.2%. Our PC business continued to gain share and achieve record high market share. In smartphone, we record a strong growth of 3.4x year-on-year in EMEA, driven by the momentum from both Lenovo and the Motorola brand.
In America. Revenue was up 49% year-on-year to about $12.2 billion, largely due to the addition of the System x and the Motorola businesses. We record a profit of $8 million in the region, largely due to the challenges in Brazil and the ramping up of the newly acquired businesses. For PC, we continue to deliver solid growth in the PC business in North America region and achieve a record high market share with margin improvement year-on-year in the fiscal year. With the continuation of the strong shipment performance of Motorola, our smartphone shipment grew about 30x year-on-year in the American region for the fiscal year. For Enterprise, we're preparing the foundation to attack and capture more Enterprise customers in the near future. 
However, our performance in Brazil was still impacted by the weak market environment, which resulted in weak demand as well as relatively high inventory in the market. Currency fluctuation also negatively impacted Lenovo as well as the Motorola performance despite its strong revenue growth momentum. We have been refining our business strategy in PC, and actions are in place to stabilize the Brazil business. Proactive actions taken -- are taken to improve our performance, includes simplifying our product portfolio, improving operational control and supply chain efficiency, as well as we actually have a new local leadership team in place to execute our strategy.
Looking ahead, it is clear that the Internet will continue to impact the market as far as the industry. As Yuanqing just mentioned, we are now taking proactive actions to transform ourself from a product-centric to a customer-centric company so as to actively engage customer, thus to improve the overall customer experience and operational efficiency over time.
In the short term, we will continue to see the PC industry will be relatively -- the PC market will be relatively soft. We will, however, continue to leverage the ongoing consolidation trend in the PC industry to grow both share and improve profitability while scaling our operation.
For the Mobile Business Group, our legacy phone business remains challenging. With the strengthening of our online model and the launch of the new Internet start-up, ShenQi, we expect some initial results later in the year, although its contribution will not be significant financially in the early stages. Outside China, we will continue to drive our business, as we see more opportunity in the rest of the world. We expect "rest of the world" growth will continue to be stronger than that in China.
As a result of a difficult economic environment, I think, in markets where Motorola has significant business, Motorola will -- has to deal with significant challenges, including a significant depreciation of the local currency, foreign currency exchange control and also imported duties on imported products. Motorola, as a result, may not be able, in the short term, to continue to grow at a significance to the market that we saw in the last few quarters. 
In the meantime, in order for us to drive operational efficiency of the entire Mobile Business Group, we plan to accelerate the integration of Motorola operation into the Lenovo smartphone businesses. However, we are -- remain confident that we can achieve breakeven in 4 to 6 quarters after the close, as we previously planned. Actions planned to execute in the short term will only generate returns in the second half of the year.
Likewise, we are very confident of our Enterprise Business targets. The System x -- we will build System x into a $5 billion business with good margin, which we are actually on track. We expect to see continuous growth in our operational profit, that is excluding the noncash, the M&A-related accounting charges, that will be driven from scaling as well as operating efficiency enhancements. We are devoted to drive growth and outperforming the industry and, in turn, enhance our profitability over time. We are very confident in delivering the year-to-year profitable growth of the group in the new fiscal year.
Thank you. Now I will -- we can take your questions.

componenttext: So about our smartphone business in China. So currently, the challenge is the market is shifting from the carrier market into the open market and to the online market. So actually, carrier market or subsidy model dropped from more than 50% to now less than 38%. So we were very strong in the carrier market. So we -- now we need to build our strong position in the open market and in the online market. So actually, we have realized this challenge 1 year or even more before. So we have started to build our capability in the open market and in the online market. So actually, we launched our Lenovo smartphone with JD.com. We will launch another product called the VIBE Shot. We actually showed at the MWC in Barcelona. So soon, we will launch that with the Tmall of Alibaba, so very, very, very soon. We have seen very -- some very positive results, although it's very unusual. First step of success, but I think it's a good signal. So we are moving faster and are determined to the online -- to the open market. Definitely, ShenQi is another weapon. We have worked there for quite a while, so of that team [ph]. So probably, they will launch another product with a different brand, so more Internet-related model, so very soon. For the carrier market, we still -- we will not give up that market, but we will more focus on the profitability. So with this strategy and change, so we are very confident. So by the end of the year, so we can have the positive profit as we'll recover the growth in that market. But to be frank, so China market now is not as attractive as the rest of the world. From the 1 aspect, the growth is very limited or is declining. From the other aspect, the competition is very fierce. I will say, it's not reasonable, it's not reasonable. Some players just disclosed their ball [ph], so -- and clearly tell you, we don't want to make money, so we see all the costs. So that's not reasonable competition. So that's why we pay more attention to the rest of the world. Actually, we have seen a very good result, very positive results. Outside China now accounts for 56% of our total volume last quarter. It will further grow over time, particularly with the Lenovo brand in emerging market. We grow faster, and we make money, like in India, in Indonesia, Southeast Asia, Middle East, Africa, Eastern Europe. So our growth are pretty dramatic, and the profit are pretty good. Actually, this is Lenovo's unique advantage after we acquired the Motorola business. We don't have an IP issue. So that's different from most of Chinese players. So they cannot go overseas. headline: Lenovo Group Limited, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2015
componenttext:
Good morning, and good evening. Welcome to Lenovo's Q1 Result Webcast. This is Gary Ng, VP, Investor Relations at Lenovo. We will first have remarks by our Chairman and CEO, Mr. Yang Yuanqing; and our CFO, Mr. Wong Wai Ming. After that, we'll take your questions.

headline: Lenovo Group Limited, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2015
componenttext:
Hello, everyone. Thank you for joining us. I will firstly discuss our last quarter results and then talk about some important strategic initiatives. Last quarter, we faced severe challenges in the market. The PC market declined significantly and faster than expected because of lower inventories ahead of Windows 10 launch and the currency depreciation. The currency fluctuations and the broad macroeconomic issues in Brazil and in the entire Latin America constrained the growth and impacted the profitability of Motorola because of the higher concentration of its business there. 
In China, smartphone market shift from more carrier speeded up, and the competition become more intensified. In fact, it was perhaps the toughest quarter, especially for PCs, since the 2008 and the 2009 global financial crisis. But Lenovo continued to deliver solid performance despite these challenges. Our PC business, still our solid core business, reached the record worldwide share while improving margins year-on-year, although revenue and profit declined with the market. 
In tablets, we outgrew the market by 12 points and narrowed the gap with top 2. In our Enterprise Business, Lenovo ThinkServer business grew faster with revenue up 41% year-on-year, especially in China where ThinkServer revenue were up 56% year-on-year. Lenovo regained #1 in China's x86 server market. We have delivered the operational profit in the combined enterprise business for the third straight quarter. 
In smartphones, our strategic shift from China to rest of the world has paid off. Our volume outside China is now 65% of the total compared with 18% a year ago. Lenovo-branded smartphones outside of China grew volume by 68% year-on-year, and it was profitable. 
Our overall phone volume grew in Middle East and Africa by 380%, Asia Pacific by 82% and the Eastern Europe by 36%. In the biggest emerging markets, Brazil, Russia and India, our overall market share reached the 21%, 10% and 6%, respectively. And we ranked at #2, #2 and #5. But our Motorola business was affected by the macroeconomic issues in Latin America and other markets. This, coupled with the higher cost structure and the longer product life cycle, has resulted in worse-than-expected losses and impacted our overall performance in profit. We will talk about our actions to fix this later. 
For Lenovo overall, revenue grew 3% year-on-year, or actually 10% if excluding exchange-related impact, reaching $10.7 billion. Net income before M&A accounting charges was down 8% year-on-year to USD 196 million. Although these are pretty solid results in a tough environment, we realized we must act quickly, proactively and decisively to meet these market challenges. Our core PC business is strong and competitive and our foundation is solid, but we must react to the faster-than-expected market decline and reduce the fixed expenses in order to leverage industry consolidation to gain more share. We will keep raising the bar of efficiency for the industry and continue to deliver margin improvement so that this business can provide the capital for the growth of the new businesses. 
Mobile and Enterprise businesses are new growth engine for our future, and their strategic importance remains unchanged. We are still in the process of aligning elements of the acquired businesses with our legacy business and building the right business model and cost structure. On one hand, I want you to understand that turning them into our profit pool still needs more efforts, and it will take some time. On the other hand, we are fully aware that we must take immediate actions to deliver our commitments. We have made progress integrating Enterprise business. But with the challenges in U.S. and other mature markets, we will do more and ensure we build a highly efficient cost structure to deliver the growth and the profitability. We will invest in the fastest-growth segments, high-volume servers, hyperscale and the converged systems, while improving our global sales force.
We will further drive the hypergrowth in China and other potential markets. In smartphones, it's time, it's necessary to further align key elements of Motorola with Lenovo to leverage our complementary strength, to reduce redundancy, to cut cost and the expenses and to improve efficiency. We will build much simpler, more efficient organizations and processes, which will become our solid foundation to success. Motorola will take the lead in product development, design, engineering and manufacturing, while Lenovo will fully leverage our global sales force to drive growth. We will have a much simpler product portfolio and eliminate redundancies. After finishing this, it will help us save around USD 850 million per year. 
Totally, with these actions, Lenovo will reduce its workforce by about 3,200 people in nonmanufacturing workforce worldwide, which equates to 10% of our total nonmanufacturing workforce and 5% of our total population. Most of this will be completed in fiscal Q2. When this action is completed, we expect to deliver $1.35 billion of annualized savings in operating expenses with our restructuring costs of about $600 million and a materialized $650 million in savings for the second half of this fiscal year. This is tough but the right decision to improve our competitiveness and to better focus our resources in this fast-changing market. We expect these efforts to help achieve our previous commitments. In PCs, our goal is still to achieve 30% market share. And in Enterprise, starting from $5 billion yearly business, we want to deliver sustainable growth with good margin. In Mobile, we remain firm to our goal of achieving breakeven in 2 to 3 quarters, and we aim at being a solid #3. 
More broadly, throughout the company, we are working on Lenovo's transformation through developing our unique competitive advantages. We are building our direct sales capabilities. We are combining our offline channel and service capabilities with online sales opportunities. We are exploring innovative ways of providing personalized and customized services to our customers. I believe this is the right decision, and I have confidence in the team's ability to precisely execute. And we will continue to deliver meaningful innovation in our products after showcasing our forward-looking technologies at the Tech World such as Smart Case and the Magic View. We will launch the new wave of mobile phones, and you can look for us to make a splash at the IFA next month in Berlin with a wave of new holiday PCs, tablets and the wearables. When we emerge from these actions, the short term and the long term, we will be a stronger company that has built unique competitive advantages, not only in efficiency but also in innovation. 
Now let me turn you to our CFO, Wai Ming. Wai Ming, please?

headline: Lenovo Group Limited, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2015
componenttext:
Thank you, Yuanqing. I will take you through Lenovo's financial and operational performance in Q1 fiscal year 2016. Next chart, please. Our group revenue increased 3% year-on-year to $10.7 billion. Excluding the currency impacts, the group revenue was up 10% year-on-year. Gross profit increased 22% year-on-year with margin improved to 15.4%, driven by better PC margin benefited from scaling and higher gross margin of newly acquired businesses. Operating expenses increased by 47% to around $1.6 billion. The increase in E-to-R ratio for the quarter is mainly driven by the 2 acquired businesses. We recorded net other nonoperating expenses of $44 million, which mainly included interest expenses from USD 1.5 billion 5-year notes we issued in May last year, the RMB 4 billion notes issued in this June and the included interest expense from Motorola deal-related promissory notes. 
PDI was $52 million. We recorded a tax credit of $50 million for the quarter associated with the losses incurred in Motorola and System x businesses. Profit for the period was $102 million, and profit attributable to equity holders was $105 million. The difference between the 2 profit lines is due to the sharing of operating loss in relation to the Compal joint venture recorded in the quarter.
Next chart, please. In this chart, we have provided a bridge to reconcile different financial figures to give you an overview and how these figures are calculated. The noncash M&A-related accounting charges related to the 2 M&A transactions were $91 million, which include intangible asset amortization of System x and Motorola, included interest expense of the 3-year promissory note issue as part of the Motorola transaction and others.
Next chart, please. There are no significant changes to our balance sheet since 31st March, 2015. The noncurrent assets were about $11.8 billion, and current assets were about $14.9 billion as of 30th of June, 2015. We had net current liabilities of around $1.3 billion at the end of the quarter, which was slightly lower than that in the March end. The noncurrent liabilities were around $6.4 billion.
Next chart, please. We reported an operating cash flow of $310 million, which was driven by payments in Q1 for expenses accrued in last financial year, including year-end bonuses, taxation and business partner incentives. The cash conversion cycle for the quarter was positive 5 days against negative 6 days the same quarter last year and positive 3 days last quarter. The positive cash conversion cycle was driven by a higher mix of mobility and consumer businesses, which normally have longer receivable dates. We will take necessary actions to tighten up the credit periods for those businesses in order to achieve a better working capital performance.
Next chart, please. PC business group. We continue to outperform the markets, even though the market continued to slow down, and gained share in all geos. Our PC revenue decreased by 13% year-on-year to $7.3 billion. Excluding currency impacts, the revenue decline would be about 5% year-on-year. Pretax margin was up slightly to 5.1% and benefited from the effective margin management and scaling benefits, while our PC ASP remained stable. 
Mobile Business Group. Our smartphone business outside China, especially in the emerging markets, continued to record strong growth, but our legacy business in China was impacted by overinvesting in the carrier channels as well as intense competition in tough market environments. Motorola has a significant business in Brazil and Latin America, and this business was significantly affected by the weak economy as well as the depreciating currency in those markets. We remain #3 tablet player worldwide. Shipment grew 4% year-to-year to 2.5 million, and our market share was up 0.7 points to 5.6%. 
For MBG, revenue increased 33% year-on-year to $2.1 billion, helped by the inclusion of the Motorola business. We recorded loss before taxation of USD 292 million and a negative 13.8% pretax margin, largely due to the softness in markets where we have significant business as well as the relatively high fixed cost. 
Enterprise Business Group. Revenue of Enterprise Business Group showed an increase of 5.8x year-on-year to $1.1 billion, helped by the inclusion of the System x business. We recorded operational profits before the noncash M&A accounting charges in the combined Enterprise business for the past 3 straight quarters.
Next chart, please. China. Revenue from China was $3.2 billion, down 16% year-on-year, while PDI was $153 million and operating margin was 4.8%, declined by 0.7 percentage points year-on-year, largely driven by the weak smartphone performance. We maintained a strong #1 position in China PC, despite market challenges, while holding up margin. Our EBG revenue grew 235%, and we regained the #1 position in the x86 server markets in China.
Asia Pacific. Japan is a principal driver for the decline of the AP PC market. Not only the market was affected by the weak economy, Japan also enjoyed the benefit brought from having help from the Window XP refreshment in quarter 1 last year. We continue to grow PC units in other AP regions and gain share, particularly in ANZ. Our smartphone business achieved strong growth in this region, including ASEAN and India, driven by substantial growth of the Lenovo brand phones and inorganic help of Motorola. As a result, our revenue in AP continued to grow year-on-year. While our PC margin improved year-on-year, the overall AP margin recorded a decline, mainly due to the challenges from Motorola. 
EMEA. The PC market in EMEA recorded a decline in quarter 1 as demand was impacted by the macro challenges and currency fluctuation. Our PC shipment and revenue were down as a result, even though we continue to achieve share gain and year-on-year margin improvement. Our smartphone and Enterprise business are still in the investment phase. We are seeing good progress in our Lenovo brand phone in EMEA. Our EMEA revenue was down by 5% to $2.6 billion. Profit before tax was $40 million, and operating margin was 1.5%.
Americas. Our PC unit shipments in North America remained strong with record high market share, driven by strong growth in consumer business. However, this strong performance was offset by slow performance in the challenging Brazilian market. This weak macroeconomic environment in Brazil has also impacted our smartphone businesses, particularly the Motorola business in Latin America and Brazil account for a substantial part of this business. 
Americas revenue was up 46% year-on-year to about $3.3 billion, helped by the addition of System x and Motorola businesses. We recorded an operating loss of $131 million in the region, mainly attributable to the losses in Brazil and Motorola businesses. As Yuanqing mentioned, we announced today our business realignment plan to enhance the company's overall competitiveness and to drive consistent, healthy profitable growth in all of our businesses. The business realignment plan aims to reduce our annualized operating expense by approximately $1.35 billion, and we expect approximately $650 million of such savings realized in the second half of the fiscal year. As a result of the realignment plan, there will be a onetime expense expected to be charged in quarter 2, which comprises of approximately $600 million restructuring charges and approximately $300 million additional spending to clear our smartphone inventory. 
The actions taken under the business realignment plan will enable us to continue to maintain our profitability and gain market share for our PC business. For EBG, we are on track to drive good operating margin with $5 billion annual turnover going forward. We continue to manage our MBG business to drive more efficiency and believe that the business can achieve an operational breakeven position in about 2 to 3 quarters. We will continue to invest in areas we believe are important to us, and we remain committed to our protect-and-attack strategy to drive better return to our shareholders. Thank you. 
Now we can take your questions.
